greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Smallest weak prime in base n.
comment: In base b, a prime is said to be weakly prime if changing any digit produces only composite numbers. Tao proves that in any fixed base there are an infinite number of weakly primes.
In particular, changing the leading digit to 0 must produce a composite number. These are also called weak primes, weakly primes, and isolated primes. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, May 06 2019
link: Terence Tao, A remark on primality testing and decimal expansions, arXiv:0802.3361 [math.NT], 2008.
Terence Tao, A remark on primality testing and decimal expansions, Journal of the Australian Mathematical Society 91:3 (2011), pp. 405-413.
mathematica: isWeak[n_, base_] := Module[{d, e, weak, num}, d = IntegerDigits[n, base]; weak = True; Do[e = d; e[[i]] = j; num = FromDigits[e, base]; If[num != n && PrimeQ[num], weak = False; Break[]], {i, Length[d]}, {j, 0, base - 1}]; weak]; Table[p = 2; While[! isWeak[p, n], p = NextPrime[p]]; p, {n, 2, 16}]
results.author: _T. D. Noe_, Mar 01 2011
